awd_titl_txt: Summer Program on Game Theory and Economics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a series of conferences and workshops in game theory and applications of game theory. The conference, follow-on workshops, and lectures are held each summer as a coordinated program designed to bring together a distinguished group of senior scientists from around the globe with junior faculty and graduate students from across the U.S. Topics include new developments in game theory, areas in the intersection between game theory and computer science (such as Computation and Privacy), and applications of game theory to business and public policy. The activities advance science by giving young scholars the opportunity to form new research collaborations and present their work to a distinguished audience. 

Topics include cooperative game theory, The Interface of Economics and Computing, Machine Learning and Data Science, Strategic Communication and Learning, Mechanism Design, Agents with Mis-specified models, Pricing in Complex Markets, Learning, Contagion, and Coordination in Networks, Delegation as an Economic Phenomenon, Game Theory and Computation, Matching Theory and Applications, Game Theory in Operations Research, Decision Theory, and Advances in Learning Theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The initial award for the project was initially meant for the three-year period 2018-2020. On account of the COVID-19 pandemic, it was actually used for five years instead of three, since the summer activities of 2020 and 2021 were done online by Zoom at virtually no cost and with enormous success, reflected in the presence of over 1000 participants from around the world in each of 2020 and 2021.

The major outcome of the project was to promote intensive interaction between young and established researchers, from all over the world, in the field of Game Theory and its applications, especially to economics. Five International Conferences, as well as nine workshops, were held in the five-year period. The major cutting-edge results in game theory and its applications were presented and discussed. Many young researchers had an opportunity to present their work and get feedback from senior scholars.

In the pandemic years 2020 and 2021, we used Virtual Chair, in conjunction with Zoom, which enabled intense interaction of over 1000 international scholars and graduate students in each year. In the other three years (2018, 2019, 2022), the summer activities were held as usual in-person and attracted over 300 participants each year.

In addition to the five annual international conferences, we had nine workshops in 2018-2022 on the following wide variety of topics: Stopping Time Problems in Game Theory, Economics and Finance; New Directions in Mechanism Design; Simplicity and Robustness in Complex Markets; Differential Games; Distributed Ledger and Economics; Strategic Communication and Learning; Innovation and Licensing; Stochastic Games: theory and computational aspects;  and Workshop on Dynamic Games in Macroeconomics and Public Finance.

The project contributed to the interaction between scholars, with emphasis on advanced graduate students, junior and senior researchers. The presentations in the conference and workshop sessions fostered a better understanding of the most recent results in the area of Game Theory and its applications in many fields, with a prominent emphasis on Economics.

The NSF grants made the Stony Brook Center for Game Theory and its summer activities a focal point that attracts both the most accomplished and the most promising scholars from around the world every year. We make every effort to select the organizers of the academic activities will cover a broad spectrum of specializations and diversity (young, women, etc.)

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2022
Modified by: Yair Tauman
